journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering

title-group.article-title: Brake judder analysis using a car rigid–flexible coupling model

article-meta.aff: 1State Key Laboratory of Automotive Simulation and Control, Jilin University, Changchun, People’s Republic of China
2Changan Automobile Engineering Institute, Chongqing, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: *College of Automotive Engineering, Jilin University, No. 5988 Renmin Street, Changchun 130022, People’s Republic of China. email: shumingchen@yahoo.cn

abstract.p: In order to understand the brake judder of a passenger car, the brake judder test of a passenger car was performed with initial speeds of 90, 120, and 150 km/h, end speed of 20 km/h, and pedal forces of 25, 30, 35, and 40 N on a roller dynamometer in a semi-anechoic chamber. The pressure fluctuation of the brake fluid pipe was presented. The accelerations of the steering wheel were recorded at vertical, lateral, and radial directions respectively, and the frequency analysis of the brake judder was also performed. The frequency response functions of the steering system were measured in order to understand the cause of the brake judder. Meanwhile, the multibody system dynamics model of the test vehicle was created with a flexible body and steering system. The brake torque calculated with the brake fluid pressure of the brake pipe in the brake judder test was exerted on the brake systems. The simulated accelerations of the steering wheel were calculated at three different directions, and the frequency analysis of the brake judder was also presented. The design of experiment was presented in order to reduce the brake judder and improve the comfort of the vehicle. An orthogonal array table was designed with 13 factors and 3 levels. The optimum combination was confirmed. The brake judder was also simulated, and the accelerations of the steering wheel were also calculated. Furthermore, the optimization results were verified by the brake judder test. The verification of the optimization indicates that the optimization results are correct and effective.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: Steering system NVH (noise, vibration, and harshness) is one of the main characteristics influencing driving comfort and safety. Brake judder is the vibration caused by brake torque variation (BTV) during the brake process [1, 2], and it is a kind of low-frequency brake vibration phenomenon. Brake judder can also cause steering wheel wobbling, driver seat shaking, brake pedal pulsation, instrument panel vibration, and body shaking. Also, brake judder can affect the prospective buyer’s inclination to purchase a passenger car, damage commercial competition, and cause a large amount of service cost [3]. Some efforts have been made to improve vehicle driving comfort in terms of judder by the automotive industry. Especially, vehicle suppliers have worked to minimize the input force through proper design of the brake system, appropriate selection of brake pad material, and good manufacturing process of tyre–wheel balancing [4, 5].

Generally, brake judder is composed of cold judder and hot judder. The main reasons for cold judder are assembly tolerance, the initial machining accuracy of the disc, and permanent deformation of the disc from the frictional heat on braking. One of the dominant causes of brake torque variation is disc thickness variation owing to uneven disc wear caused by lateral runout and the drag force of the brake cornering system. However, hot judder is caused by the disturbance due to the friction between the disc and pad, or the thermal deflection of disc. As a result, hot judder exhibits at a higher order of the wheel rotational speed [6, 7].

In recent years, numerous attempts have been made to analyse the brake judder phenomenon using simulation tools. Multibody system dynamics has been noted to be a conductive tool for many applications. Hussain et al. created a two-dimensional and a three-dimensional commercial vehicle model, and investigated the transmission of vibration in the form of judder from the brake of a commercial vehicle to the cab and driver [8]. Kim et al. [9] built a multibody system dynamics model of a brake system and investigated the influence factors of the brake cornering system to reduce brake torque variation. Meyer analysed the excitation and transmission mechanism of brake judder using the coupled brake, chassis, and steering system [10]. Sensitivity analysis is widely used in the brake judder phenomenon. Singh et al. [11] investigated the suspension sensitivity to brake judder. Yu et al. [12] analysed the vehicle chassis transmissibility of steering shimmy and brake judder using virtual design of experiment. Hwang and Park [13] calculated the judder sensitivity on the basis of design sensitivity analysis. Boulahbal [14] presented a unified framework for addressing NVH-related issues attributed to tyre uniformity and brake rotor DTV. Some researchers also investigated the thermal brake judder, analysed the mechanism of hot brake judder, and presented various measures to reduce thermal brake judder [15, 16].

In this research, a brake judder test was performed with a passenger car, and the brake judder of the car was analysed in the time and frequency domains. The causes of the brake judder were also discussed. In order to reduce the brake judder and improve the ride comfort of the car, a design of experiment was performed. Subsequently, the optimal results were also verified.

sec.title: 2.1 Set-up of the brake judder test
sec.p: A passenger car with the brake judder phenomenon was made ready for the tests. A total of 10 triaxial acceleration transducers were installed on various chassis components. Two accelerometers were mounted on each caliper. Two accelerometers were mounted on each bracket. Two accelerometers were mounted on the bottom of each steering knuckle arm. Two accelerometers were mounted on the bottom of each steering tie rod, with one of the directions of the accelerometers being along the axis of the steering tie rod. One accelerometer was mounted on the bottom of the steering universal joint. Also, one accelerometer was mounted on the steering wheel. The directions of the acceleration transducer shown in Fig. 1 were vertical, lateral, and radial of the steering wheel. Meanwhile, a hydraulic pressure transducer was mounted on the brake fluid pipeline of the brake system and was used for measuring the brake fluid pressure, as shown in Fig. 2. A special pedal force transducer was mounted on the brake pedal to monitor the change of the pedal force during the brake process; the installing position of the brake pedal force transducer is shown in Fig. 3. A GPS velocity transducer was used to record the change in the velocity of the passenger car during the brake process.

caption.p: Directions of the acceleration transducer mounted on the steering wheel
Installed position of the brake fluid pressure transducer
Installed position of the pedal force transducer

sec.p: The brake judder test was performed on a roller dynamometer through a driving cycle, as demonstrated in Table 1. The initial brake velocities were 90, 120, and 150 km/h, and the braking end velocity was 20 km/h. Every braking operation was conducted at a pedal force of 25, 30, 35, and 40 N. The braking operation was conducted three times for every case. The test was performed by braking and dwelling. The disc was cooled to the normal temperature by using a ventilator before a second braking test began.

caption.p: Brake judder test cycle on the roller dynamometer

sec.title: 2.2 Analysis of the brake judder
sec.p: The brake fluid pressure fluctuation is shown in Fig. 4. It is obvious that the fluctuation of the brake fluid pressure occurs at pedal force of 30 N and initial brake velocity of 120 km/h. The fluctuation of the brake fluid pressure becomes stronger as the velocity of the car decreases. The brake fluid pressure fluctuation is mainly caused by the disc thickness variation. Drivers can feel brake fluid pressure pulsation when the value of DTV is larger than 15 μm.

caption.p: Brake fluid pressure curve (pedal force 30 N, initial brake velocity 120 km/h)

sec.p: The brake judder appears in the vertical and lateral directions obviously, while the brake judder in the radial direction was found to be insignificant. The vertical vibration acceleration curve of the steering wheel is shown in Fig. 5. The judder starts at 84 km/h and the amplitude of the judder gradually increases, the maximum amplitude of the judder occurs at the vertical direction, and the peak value is 2.4 g at a velocity of 62 km/h. Then, the judder gradually disappears with a vehicle speed decrease. The lateral vibration of the steering wheel is shown in Fig. 6. The brake judder also starts at 84 km/h and the amplitude of the judder gradually increases, the maximum amplitude of the judder occurs at a velocity of 63 km/h, and the peak value is 2.75 g. The brake judder phenomenon gradually disappears as the velocity of the vehicle slows down. The start velocities of the brake judder generation are nearly the same in the vertical directions. However, the maximum amplitude of the steering wheel vibrations in the lateral direction is 0.35 g larger than the corresponding value in the vertical direction. The radial vibration of the steering wheel is shown in Fig. 7. The brake judder starts at 85 km/h and the amplitude of the judder also gradually increases. The peak value of the radial vibration of the steering wheel is 1.5 g at a speed of 67 km/h. The peak value is lower than the corresponding peak values in the lateral and vertical directions.

caption.p: Vertical vibration acceleration curve of the steering wheel (pedal force 30 N, initial brake velocity 120 km/h)
Lateral vibration acceleration curve of the steering wheel (pedal force 30 N, initial brake velocity 120 km/h)
Radial vibration acceleration curve of the steering wheel (pedal force 30 N, initial brake velocity 120 km/h)

sec.p: In order to analyse the frequency characteristic, the frequency spectrums of the steering wheel vibration in the vertical, lateral, and radial directions were calculated respectively. The frequency spectrums are shown in Fig. 8. There is a peak value for the vertical vibration of the steering wheel at 15.34 Hz and the peak value is 0.5 g. The frequency spectrums of lateral and radial vibrations of the steering wheel also have peak values at 15.34 Hz and the peak values are lower than the corresponding value of the vertical vibration. The vibration frequency is related to the rotation speed of the wheel. The corresponding rotation speed of the wheel is 900 r/min when the vibration frequency is 15 Hz. The peak values occur at the same frequency of 33.84 Hz for three direction vibrations of the steering wheel and the peak values are 0.57, 0.31, and 0.11 g for lateral, radial, and vertical vibrations respectively. Also, there are peak values at 22.18 Hz for lateral and radial vibrations of the steering wheel. The vertical vibration of the steering wheel plays a major role in judder in the first-order harmonic frequency of 15.34 Hz. However, the lateral vibration of the steering wheel plays a major role in the second-order harmonic frequency of 33.84 Hz. The vertical vibration of the steering wheel is significant and directly impacts the frequency of 15 Hz. From the brake judder experiment, it is verified that the vertical vibration near 15 Hz is the major cause of the brake judder.

caption.p: Frequency spectrums of the steering wheel vibration in the vertical, lateral, and radial directions

sec.title: 2.3 Cause analysis for brake judder
sec.p: The steering wheel vibration can be caused for several reasons, including brake judder, an inherent characteristic of the steering system. If the natural frequency of the steering system is near to the outside excitation frequency, the steering wheel may generate resonance vibration. Additionally, steering wheel vibration may be caused by brake judder, which itself is affected by brake torque variation, disc thickness variations, etc.

In order to know the relationship between the natural characteristic of the steering system and the vibration of the steering wheel, the frequency response functions (FRFs) of the steering system were measured. The installations of acceleration transducers were the same as the set-up of the brake judder test. The steering wheel was impacted with a hammer at vertical, lateral, and radial directions. Meanwhile, the responses of the steering knuckle arm, anti-roll bar, etc., were measured.

The FRFs of the three directions of the steering knuckle arm to the vertical direction of the steering wheel are shown in Fig. 9. The vertically related frequency characteristic can be well represented through vertical excitation. The vertical direction vibration of the steering knuckle arm plays a significant role in natural properties of the steering system at 32.70 Hz. The vibration peaks are noted at 24.04, 28.37, 35.11, and 38.00 Hz for longitudinal excitation and at 32.32 and 36.07 Hz for lateral excitation.

caption.p: Frequency response functions of the three directions of the steering knuckle arm to the vertical direction of the steering wheel

sec.p: The FRFs of the three directions of the steering knuckle arm to the lateral direction of the steering wheel are shown in Fig. 10. The laterally related frequency characteristic can be well represented through lateral excitation. The resonance peak can be observed at 37.20 Hz.

caption.p: Frequency response functions of the three directions of the steering knuckle arm to the lateral direction of the steering wheel

sec.p: The FRFs of the three directions of the steering knuckle arm to the radial direction of the steering wheel are shown in Fig. 11. The resonance occurs at 32.03 Hz with vertical excitation. There is a peak value at 35.11 Hz with longitudinal excitation.

caption.p: Frequency response functions of the three directions of the steering knuckle arm to the radial direction of the steering wheel

sec.p: It is found that the resonance frequency of 15.34 Hz is caused by actual braking, which is different from the resonance frequency from 25 to 35 Hz that is caused by the hammer impact test because of the non-linearity of the steering system. The resonance frequency around 33 Hz is near to the second-order harmonic frequency of the steering wheel. The vibration at this frequency band may be caused by braking and natural characteristics of the steering system. The vibrations excited by wheels are transferred to the driver through the steering knuckle arm, tie rod, steering column, and steering wheel. Thus, steering system characteristics can be improved to isolate the vibration efficiently in the vibration transfer path.

sec.title: 3 Multibody System Dynamics Modelling of a Passenger Car
sec.p: The study was based on a passenger car. The multibody system dynamics model was constructed using ADAMS commercial software. The front suspension shown in Fig. 12 was modelled as a Macpherson strut with an L-shaped lower control arm; and the overall multi-body system dynamics model of the passenger car is shown in Fig. 13. Most of the parts including control arms and knuckles were modelled as rigid parts with mass and inertia properties. The bushings were created as linear and non-linear elements. The brake caliper was created as a lumped rigid mass and the brake rotor was modelled with corresponding location, mass, and inertia properties. In order to simplify the multibody system dynamics model of the car, the parts and assemblies including the front/rear suspension, wheel, powertrain, etc., are rigid. However, the influence of more details on brake judder can not be considered. For the purpose of obtaining accurate results of brake judder, some flexible parts were taken into consideration. During modelling, the steering wheel, steering column, and steering axis of the steering system were built as flexible parts, and the flexible steering system is shown in Fig. 14. Meanwhile, the stabilizer bar and the twist beam of the rear suspension were also built as flexible parts; the stabilizer bar is shown in Fig. 15 and the twist beam of the rear suspension is shown in Fig. 16.

caption.p: Front suspension model
Car multibody system dynamics model
Steering system
Stabilizer bar
Twist beam of the rear suspension

sec.p: Brake judder is demonstrated in the multibody system dynamics model using a brake torque variation on the wheel. The mathematical description of the brake torque variation is shown in Fig. 17. It is assumed that brake torque M occurring in the process of brake judder can be expressed as
where M0 is the constant brake torque, MD is the brake torque variation caused by DTV, ω is the angular frequency, where ω can be written as
where n is the number of DTVs per circle and φ′ is the rotary angle of the wheel.

caption.p: Mathematical description of DTV

sec.p: The order n =1 is used to correspond to the first-order excitation measured in the brake judder test. Thus, the excitation frequency can be given by
It is also assumed that the sinusoidal brake torque varies on the front wheels, and the left and right excitations are in phase opposition. The left and right brake torque can be expressed as follows
The relationship between the brake torque and brake fluid pressure of the brake pipe can be expressed as
where μ is the friction coefficient, P is the brake fluid pressure of the brake pipe, S is the area of the brake wheel cylinder, and R is the effective brake radius.

According to the equation (7), the brake torque was calculated based on the measured brake fluid pressure of the brake pipe, and the brake torque at 30 N of pedal force is shown in Fig. 18. The brake torque is near to the sinusoidal signal. However, it fluctuates in a periodic time. The maximum and minimum brake torques are 437.8 and 395.3 N m respectively. Also, the fluctuation range is from 0 to 42.5 N m.

caption.p: Measured curve of the brake torque

sec.p: The brake torque was applied to all four wheels with 80 per cent front and 20 per cent rear distribution. The excitation frequency changed as the speed of the car decreases. The whole frequency range from 0 to 20 Hz was excited as the car speed decreases from 120 to 20 km/h. The phenomenon of the brake judder can be observed with the proper frequency excitation at the corresponding car driving speeds. The brake torque of the model was calculated according to the measured brake torque, and shown in Fig. 19.

caption.p: Simulated curve of the brake torque

sec.title: 4 Simulation Results of the Brake Judder
sec.p: The brake judder simulation was conducted at the same conditions as the brake judder test. The vertical, lateral, and radial accelerations of the steering wheel were measured at the steering wheel rim. The vertical acceleration of the steering wheel is shown in Fig. 20. The amplitude of the judder is gradually increasing as the car speed decreases and the maximum amplitude of the judder is 2.48 g at the speed of 60 km/h. Then, the judder gradually disappears. The lateral vibration of the steering wheel is shown in Fig. 21. The maximum amplitude of the lateral acceleration is 2.48 g. The radial acceleration of the steering wheel is shown in Fig. 22. The judder phenomenon is not obvious at the radial direction.

caption.p: Vertical vibration simulation curve of the steering wheel
Lateral vibration simulation curve of the steering wheel
Radial vibration simulation curve of the steering wheel

sec.p: The frequency spectrums of the simulation results of the brake judder at three different directions are shown in Fig. 23. There are only three peak frequencies for the vertical, lateral, and radial directions. There is a peak value for the vertical vibration of the steering wheel at 15.09 Hz and the peak value is 0.45 g. The peak value and the frequency of the simulation are close to the corresponding values of the test in the vertical direction. The frequency spectrums of lateral vibration of the steering wheel have a peak value of 0.21 g at 15.23 Hz, and the peak value is 0.24 g lower than the corresponding value of the vertical vibration. The judder frequency in the radial direction is 14.70 Hz, which is a little lower than the corresponding values in the vertical and lateral directions, and the peak value in the radial direction is 0.09 g, which is also lower than the corresponding values in the vertical and lateral directions.

caption.p: Frequency spectrums of the simulation results of the brake judder

sec.title: 5.1 Orthogonal array table
sec.p: The brake judder performance is significantly influenced by suspension characteristics. A sensitivity analysis was presented to identify the design variables that influence brake judder in the Macpherson strut suspension system of the test car. The design variables are shown in Table 2. Four different parts, including the lower control arm, subframe, tyre, and top mount bush of the front suspension, were confirmed, and the stiffness of the bushes in the x, y, and z directions, including front and rear bush stiffness of the lower control arm, mount bush stiffness of the subframe, tyre stiffness, and top mount bush stiffness of the front suspension, were selected to be the design variables. The top mount bush is a part connected to the body.

caption.p: Design variables

sec.p: Thousands of experiments will be needed with full arrangements if the experiment is designed with 13 factors and 3 levels. It is time consuming and ineffective. Thus, an orthogonal experiment L27(313) was designed with 13 factors and 3 levels. Thirteen factors are the front bush stiffness of the lower control arm in the x, y, and z directions, the rear bush stiffness of the lower control arm in the x, y, z directions, the mount bush stiffness of the subframe in the x, y, and z directions, the top mount bush stiffness of the suspension in the x, y, and z directions, and the tyre stiffness in the z direction. The three levels used are 50, 100, and 150 per cent of the initial value. A total of 27 experiments are required in the orthogonal experiment. The maximum acceleration of the steering wheel rim was set to be the optimization objective function, which should be minimized.

sec.title: 5.2 Statistical analysis
sec.p: A range analysis is an important analysis method in the treatment of the experiment results. According to the simple calculation results, the optimum level can be concluded. The experiment index with factor j and level k is defined asyjk; y¯jkis the average of yjk. Meanwhile, according to the value ofy¯jk, the optimum level can be determined. The optimum combination can be generated with the optimum level combination of all the factors. The range of the factor j can be expressed as
The amplitude of fluctuation of the experiment index is reflected by Rj when the factor j changes.

sec.title: 6 Analysis of Optimization Results
sec.p: The calculation results of the maximum acceleration of the steering wheel rim are shown in Table 3 for 27 experiments. The minimum acceleration is 0.65 g for treatment 19 and the maximum acceleration is 2.45 g for treatment 1. The acceleration value of the steering wheel varies between 0.65 and 2.45 g.

caption.p: Orthogonal experiments and results

tr.th: Front bush stiffness of the lower control arm
Rear bush stiffness of the lower control arm
Mount bush stiffness of the subframe
Top mount bush stiffness of the suspension

fn.p: ‘1’ denotes 0.5 times the initial stiffness, ‘2’ denotes the initial stiffness, and ‘3’ denotes 1.5 times the initial stiffness.

sec.p: According to the basic principle of the range analysis, the mean value of the different factor and level was calculated and the ranges of the different factors were also computed. The mean values and ranges are shown in Table 4.

caption.p: Average statistics of the acceleration of the steering wheel

tr.th: Front bush stiffness of the lower control arm
Rear bush stiffness of the lower control arm
Mount bush stiffness of the subframe
Top mount bush stiffness of the suspension

sec.p: Low acceleration of the steering wheel is the optimum objective of the experiment. The lowest range of the acceleration of the steering wheel is 0.17 for factor I. The average results of the experiment for factor I are 1.34, 1.51, and 1.42. The lowest average result of the experiment was 1.34 and the largest average result of the experiment was 1.51. Thus, the range was 0.17 for factor I.

As shown in Table 4, the optimum level is found for A3, B3, C3, D2, E3, F3, G2, H3, I1, J3, K1, L3, and M3. The optimum combination is the same to the optimum level. The sequence of the priority is A, E, B, D, C, G, L, H, K, F, J, M, and I. The mean value of the acceleration at different levels of each parameter is shown in Fig. 24. Basically, the lower the acceleration, the better are the multiple performance characteristics.

caption.p: Tendency of the mean values of the acceleration

sec.p: The optimum combination is A3, B3, C3, D2, E3, F3, G2, H3, I1, J3, K1, L3, and M3. Also, the acceleration of the steering wheel was calculated with the optimum combination. The vertical acceleration of the steering wheel is shown in Fig. 25. The largest acceleration of the steering wheel is 0.61 g at a speed of 55 km/h. The acceleration of the steering wheel increases first and then decreases in the process of braking. Also, the brake judder phenomenon has disappeared. The lateral acceleration of the steering wheel is shown in Fig. 26. The largest acceleration of the steering wheel is 0.59 g at speed of 59 km/h. The acceleration of the steering wheel also increases first and then decreases as the vehicle speed decreases. However, no obvious brake judder is found. The radial acceleration of the steering wheel is shown in Fig. 27. The acceleration is mainly from 0.35 g to 0.52 g, and the brake judder is not found.

caption.p: Optimized vertical acceleration of the steering wheel
Optimized lateral acceleration of the steering wheel
Optimized radial acceleration of the steering wheel

sec.title: 7 Verification of the Doe
sec.p: In order to verify the optimization results, all the bushings with modified stiffness were developed and mounted on the test car. The brake judder test was performed with the same test set-up as in section 2.1. The vertical acceleration of the steering wheel is shown in Fig. 28. The brake judder phenomenon has been eliminated at the vertical direction. The vibration fluctuates mainly between –0.6 to 0.6 g. The amplitude of the vertical acceleration is in accordance with the corresponding value of the simulation. The lateral acceleration of the steering wheel is shown in Fig. 29. The acceleration of the steering wheel increases first and then decreases as the speed of the test car decreases. The maximum acceleration of the steering wheel is 0.5 g at a speed of 60 km/h and the amplitude of the lateral acceleration varies within 0.2 g. The brake judder was fundamentally improved in the lateral direction. The radial acceleration of the steering wheel is shown in Fig. 30. The acceleration of the steering wheel varies within 0.5 g. The brake judder phenomenon is not found in the radial direction of the steering wheel. The verification of the optimization indicates that the optimization results are corrective and effective.

caption.p: Verification of the vertical acceleration of the steering wheel for the optimization
Verification of the lateral acceleration of the steering wheel for the optimization
Verification of the radial acceleration of the steering wheel for the optimization

sec.title: 8 Conclusions
sec.p: The brake judder test of a passenger car was performed with initial brake speeds of 90, 120, and 150 km/h, an end speed of 20 km/h, and pedal forces of 25, 30, 35, and 40 N on a roller dynamometer in a semi-anechoic room. The brake judder phenomenon was obvious at a pedal force of 30 N, with an initial brake speed of 120 km/h and an end speed of 20 km/h. The accelerations of the steering wheel were measured in the vertical, lateral, and radial directions. The main frequency of the brake judder is 15 Hz and the vibration is obvious in the vertical direction.

The rigid-elastic coupling system dynamics model of the car was created by considering elasticity of the steering system and some parts. The brake torque was calculated with the brake fluid pressure of the brake pipe measured in the brake judder test and was exerted on the brake systems of the virtual prototype model of the car. The simulated accelerations of the steering wheel were calculated in three different directions. The amplitudes of the brake judder were basically in accordance with the corresponding values of the test. The frequency spectrums of the brake judder were calculated and the frequency of the brake judder was also found to be 15 Hz, which was the same as the test results.

The design of experiment was presented in order to reduce the brake judder and improve the ride comfort of the car. An orthogonal array table was designed with 13 factors and 3 levels. The optimum combination was confirmed. The brake judder was also simulated, and the accelerations of the steering wheel were also calculated with optimal parameters. The acceleration of the steering wheel fluctuated within 0.6 g. The brake judder phenomenon was not found in the vertical, lateral, and radial directions. In order to verify the optimization results, all the bushings with modified stiffness were created and mounted on the test car. The brake judder test was performed with the same test set-up. The acceleration of the steering also fluctuated within 0.6 g. The verification of the optimization indicates that the optimization results are corrective and effective.
Therefore, some suggestions are presented for improving brake judder, as follows.

list-item.p: DTV should be controlled. In order to minimize the probability of brake judder caused by disc geometry, precise manufacture and installation of the disc should be adopted.

The factors including the stiffness of the front and rear bushes of the lower control arm, the mount bush stiffness of the subframe, the top mount bush stiffness of the suspension, and tyre stiffness have a significant influence on the brake judder performance. These factors can be changed to improve brake judder performances.
The disc can be manufactured by using materials with good heat dispersion, small thermoelastic distorsion, etc., in order to reduce the influence of DTV on brake judder.
